channel.title: Access Levels
channel.description:
Well, this helped me a lot, and I haven't found another one as "short and sweet" online, so I decided to share it.
This is from a book I have, it describes the different visibilities (or whatever you want to call it) of methods, variables, etc. in Java.
[table] [tr] [td][b]Visibility[/b][/td][td]public[/td][td]protected[/td][td]default*[/td][td]private[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]From the same class[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]From any class in the same package[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]No[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]No[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]From any class outside the package[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]No[/td][td]No[/td][td]No[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]From a subclass in the same package[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]No[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]From a subclass outside the same package[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]No[/td][td]No[/td] [/tr] [/table]
*Default being where you do not declare public, protected or private infront of a method or variable name.
[size=8pt]From [u]Sams Teach Yourself Java 6 in 21 Days[/u][/size]
Again, I just thought it might help some of you, I know most of you probably already know all of this stuff, but I know I had a hard time grasping this concept early on.

item.title: Access Levels

item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

Oh, I see.

Hopefully it’s fixed now.

item.title: Access Levels

item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

No, it’s wrong on the “accessible from any class in the package”.

item.title: Access Levels
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

Silver Lining:

It’s wrong on the protected modifier.

Is it the “Subclass outside the same package” one that’s wrong?

[quote=“new Nub();, post:3, topic:168059”][IMG]http://i160.photobucket.com/albums/t167/nirvanasmarijuana/AccessTable.jpg[/ img]

win?[/quote]

That works too I guess.

The Un-Named:

I think this actually explains it better.

Well, that article probably does explain it better, but I think new Nub();'s picture two posts up is probably more succinct and easier to grasp “at a glance” than either that or my original table :.

Oh well.

Read full topic

item.title: Access Levels
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

Well, this helped me a lot, and I haven’t found another one as “short and sweet” online, so I decided to share it.

This is from a book I have, it describes the different visibilities (or whatever you want to call it) of methods, variables, etc. in Java.

[table]
[tr]
[td]Visibility[/td][td]public[/td][td]protected[/td][td]default*[/td][td]private[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]From the same class[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]From any class in the same package[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]No[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]No[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]From any class outside the package[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]No[/td][td]No[/td][td]No[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]From a subclass in the same package[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]No[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]From a subclass outside the same package[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]Yes[/td][td]No[/td][td]No[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

*Default being where you do not declare public, protected or private infront of a method or variable name.

[size=8pt]From Sams Teach Yourself Java 6 in 21 Days[/size]

Again, I just thought it might help some of you, I know most of you probably already know all of this stuff, but I know I had a hard time grasping this concept early on.

Read full topic
